case_title: THE STATE vs RANA PHOOL MUHAMMAD KHAN AND OTHERS
respondant: RANA PHOOL MUHAMMAD KHAN AND OTHERS

accussed_details.name: Rana Phool Muhammad Khan
allegation: Fraudulent exchange of Evacuee Trust Property land

complaint_summary: The Evacuee Trust Property Board alleged that its land in Mianke More was fraudulently exchanged during consolidation proceedings finalized on 30-09-1968.
investigation_summary: The Board of Revenue found that the exchange was consented to by representatives of the Evacuee Trust Property Board and warranted no interference.
judgment_summary: The court dismissed the suo motu revision, stating that the exchange was consented to by the Board's representatives, and the land had been properly administered for 16 years. The court ruled that reopening the case would be unjust.
legal_arguments: Fraud vitiates everything, but no evidence of fraud was found.
The Board of Revenue has unfettered discretion in suo motu jurisdiction.
Estoppel applies as the Board accepted the exchanged land and did not challenge the scheme earlier.
assets: Evacuee Trust Property land in Mianke More
witnesses: Representatives of Evacuee Trust Property Board

witness_statement.Representatives of Evacuee Trust Propert: Confirmed the exchange and signed the register schemes.

key_issues: Validity of suo motu revisional jurisdiction after 16 years
Consent of Evacuee Trust Property Board representatives

maxims.Fraud vitiates everything: Fraud cannot be cured by consent or lapse of time.

legal_terms.Suo Motu: Action taken by a court on its own initiative.
legal_terms.Estoppel: A legal principle preventing a party from contradicting its previous statements or actions.

words_and_phrases.Consolidation Scheme: A process to reorganize land holdings for efficient use.

summary_vector_notes: The case involved allegations of fraudulent land exchange during consolidation proceedings. The court found no evidence of fraud and ruled that the exchange was consented to by the Board's representatives. The revision was dismissed due to estoppel and the lapse of time.
